questions.text: A data point that is unusual only within a specific context (e.g., high temperature in winter) is known as a:
questions.explanation: Contextual outliers are anomalous given a specific context, but not necessarily globally.

questions.text: The Z-score method for outlier detection is robust and not affected by extreme values in the dataset.
questions.explanation: The Z-score method uses the mean and standard deviation, both of which are sensitive to extreme values (outliers), making the Z-score itself less robust in such cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common strategy for handling identified outliers?

options.text: Ignoring them completely in all analyses.

questions.explanation: While sometimes outliers might be kept, completely ignoring them without understanding or specific intent is generally not a good strategy as they can significantly skew results. Other options are valid handling techniques depending on the context.
